qas.question: What metatextual character does Stefan Wild focus on in his discussion of the Quran?
What quality does the Quran claim in the different ways in which it refers to itself?
Which term that the Quran uses for itself means "news"?
The Quran is more self-referential in which of its suras?
What metatextual character doesn't Stefan Wild focus on in his discussion of the Quran?
What quality doesn't the Quran claim in the different ways in which it refers to itself?
What quality does the Quran claim in the same ways in which it refers to itself?
Which term that the Quran uses for itself doesn't mean "news"?
The Quran is less self-referential in which of its suras?

context: A text is <b4_0>self-referential<b4_0/> when it speaks about itself and makes reference to itself. According to Stefan Wild, the Quran demonstrates this metatextuality by explaining, classifying, interpreting and justifying the words to be transmitted. <a0_0>Self-referentiality<a0_0/> is evident in those passages where the Quran refers to itself as revelation (tanzil), remembrance (dhikr), news (<a2_0><b7_0>naba'<b7_0/><a2_0/>), criterion (furqan) in a self-designating manner (explicitly asserting its <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>Divinity<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>, "And this is a blessed Remembrance that We have sent down; so are you now denying it?"), or in the frequent appearance of the "Say" tags, when Muhammad is commanded to speak (e.g., "Say: 'God's guidance is the true guidance' ", "Say: 'Would you then dispute with us concerning God?' "). According to Wild the Quran is highly self-referential. The feature is more evident in <a3_0><b8_0>early Meccan suras<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
